section.title: The Rank Theorem and the Basis Theorem

ol.li: Learn to use the rank theorem and the basis theorem.

introduction.p: In this section we present two important general facts about dimensions and bases.

subsection.title: The Rank Theorem

statement.p: The rank of a matrix A, written \rank(A), is the dimension of the column space \Col(A).
The nullity of a matrix A, written \nullity(A), is the dimension of the null space \Nul(A).
If A is a matrix with n columns, then \rank(A) + \nullity(A) = n.

subsection.p: In other words, for any consistent system of linear equations, \text{(dim of column span)} + \text{(dim of solution set)} = \text{(number of variables)}. The rank theorem theorem is really the culmination of this chapter, as it gives a strong relationship between the null space of a matrix (the solution set of Ax=0) with the column space (the set of vectors b making Ax=b consistent), our two primary objects of interest.

example.title: The rank is 2 and the nullity is 2
example.p: Since there are two free variables x_3,x_4, the null space of A has two vectors (see this ): \left\{\vec{8 -4 1 0},\;\vec{7 -3 0 1}\right\}, so \nullity(A) = 2.
In this case, the rank theorem says that 2 + 2 = 4, where 4 is the number of columns.

subsection.title: The Basis Theorem
subsection.p: Recall from this that \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n\} forms a basis for \R^n if and only if the matrix A with columns v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n has a pivot in every row and column. Since A is an n\times n matrix, these two conditions are equivalent: the vectors span if and only if they are linearly independent. The basis theorem is an abstract version of the preceding statement, that applies to any subspace.

statement.p:
Let V be a subspace of dimension m. Then:
Any m linearly independent vectors in V form a basis for V.
Any m vectors that span V form a basis for V.

proof.p: Suppose that \cB = \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\} is a set of linearly independent vectors in V. In order to show that \cB is a basis for V, we must prove that V = \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\}. If not, then there exists some vector v_{m+1} in V that is not contained in \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\}. By the increasing span criterion, the set \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m,v_{m+1}\} is also linearly independent. Continuing in this way, we keep choosing vectors until we eventually do have a linearly independent spanning set: say V = \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m,\ldots,v_{m+k}\}. Then \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_{m+k}\} is a basis for V, which implies that \dim(V) = m+k > m. But we were assuming that V has dimension m, so \cB must have already been a basis.

Now suppose that \cB = \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\} spans V. If \cB is not linearly independent, then by this , we can remove some number of vectors from \cB without shrinking its span. After reordering, we can assume that we removed the last k vectors without shrinking the span, and that we cannot remove any more. Now V = \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_{m-k}\}, and \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_{m-k}\} is a basis for V because it is linearly independent. This implies that \dim V=m-k < m. But we were assuming that \dim V = m, so \cB must have already been a basis.

subsection.p:
In other words, if you already know that \dim V = m, and if you have a set of m vectors \cB = \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\} in V, then you only have to check one of:
\cB is linearly independent, or
\cB spans V,
in order for \cB to be a basis of V. If you did not already know that \dim V = m, then you would have to check both properties.
For example, if V is a plane, then any two noncollinear vectors in V form a basis.

example.title: Yet another basis for a span

solution.p:
We know from the previous examples that \dim V = 2. By the , it suffices to find any two noncollinear vectors in V. We write two linear combinations of the four given spanning vectors, chosen at random:
w_1 = \vec{1 -2 2} + \vec{2 -3 4} = \vec{3 -5 6} \qquad w_2 = -\vec{2 -3 4} + \frac 12\vec{0 4 0} = \vec{-2 5 -4}.
Since w_1,w_2 are not collinear, \cB = \{w_1,w_2\} is a basis for V.
